cab.content: TIMS poCumeITColonel W. Dally Jonesi the Property ofSECRET.His Britannic Majestys Governraer.'MINISTRY OF FOOD.146 iiT, 644 5llhllBfmtm for Week ending Wednesday, December 4, 1918. PART L-ACTION TAKEN. The Food Council. Mr. Clynes, presiding over a meeting of the Food Council,referred to the proposal to secure more beer and a reduction in prices, and emphasised the importance of the question of prices being dealt with promptly. It has been decided that it will no longer be necessary to maintain the rationing of lard. The Council have agreed to relax the following restrictions on the sale and rise ofcereals: - (1) The Cake and Pastry Order. (2) The limit on the total sale of breadstulfs for afternoon meals in catering establishments, &c. (3) The restriction on the use of maize, barley, and oats for industrial purposes. (4) The limit on the percentage of imported flour which may be mixed with G-.R. flour. (5) The restriction on the use of potatoes and potato products, except that the use of sound ware potatoes must continue to be restricted to seed or human food. (6) The restriction on the sale and use of cereals, flour, starch, &c, other than those imported by the Wheat Commission. In deference to further representations received from the Board of Trade theFood Council have decided to withdraw their objection to the publication of figuresof imports in the Board of Trade monthly returns. The Imports Board. At the Board's meeting on Thursday, November 28th, theChairman expressed the Board's appreciation of the way in which Canada and theCanada Food Board had saved the butter situation in the United Kingdom by requisi-tioning butter in Canada. Had it not been for Canada's prompt action it would nothave been possible to maintain the butter ration. Owing to a reduction in War Office requirements a greatly increased quantity ofdates from Basra will be available for civilian consumption. Provided Treasurysanction is obtained it is proposed to increase the purchases on account of the ministry to 23,500 tons. It is understood that shipping will be available. The purchase of Danish eggs is completed and it is expected that the Egyptianprogramme will be fulfilled, but the supplies of eggs from North America havefallen short of the quantity it was hoped would be purchased. The position is asfollows : Programme. Available Supplies. Shortage.U.S.A. - ' -' 90,000 cases. 30,000 ,, 65,000 cases. 5,000 ,, 25,000 cases. 25,000 ,, In view of this deficiency the suggestion has been made that supplies should beobtained from South Africa if cool space can be made available. Tonnage will be provided for importing 800 tons of dried apples, from Australiaif supplies are satisfactory. It is understood that more freight space will be available from Australia in January and February for general cargo; the Meat PurchasingCommittee have been notified accordingly. The Home Supplies Board. In view of the representations of the President ofthe Board of Agriculture deprecating the fixing of prices for root crops, it was agreedthat prices should not be fixed for turnips, swedes, beetroot, or parsnips, but that inview of the shortness of the crop a maximum price at all stagey should be fixed forcarrots. ' A (33)7008-1 Pk9 145 12/18 E&S A The Chief Live Stock Commissioner, reporting on the operations of the feeding stuffs distribution scheme, stated that after' January 25th it was hoped rationing of offals would he no longer necessary, though probably some form of rationing would still be required for cake. The Central Agricultural Advisory Council. The Council met on Tuesday, December 3rd. The question of the price of the 1919 British wool clip was discussed, and it was agreed that members of the Council who also sit on the Wool Advisory Committee of the Army Contracts Department should draw up a Report for submission to the Council at the next meeting. The Council will then be able to forward its views to the Wool Council, which is formed of Representatives of the Trade appointed by the War Office to consider the whole question of control; this Council is to meet on December 19th. A suggestion put forward by the Ministry of Food that pigs below 178 lbs. live weight should be sold by auction, and not at the fixed maximum price of 21s. per score, in order that another outlet might be provided for the surplus pigs in the market, was approved by the Council. A request from the National Agricultural Labourers' and Rural Workers' Union for representation on the Council was referred to the Standing Orders Sub-Committee for consideration. . The Development of the Margarine Industry. A food industry which has shown a remarkable development during the war is the edible oil and margarine industry. Before the war when the deodorising of oil was mainly a continental industry, and facilities both for this purpose and for hydrogenation were inconsiderable, the British margarine industry supplied only about half the home consumption which was then ,roughly 3,000 tons per week. Until the spring of 1918 we continued to import margarine from Holland, and the necessary oil was forwarded under licence to that country for the purpose. In the meantime the necessary machinery for the refining of the oil and the manufacture of margarine was being installed in this country with a view to making Great Britain self-contained so far as this important food industry is concerned. In particular, great strides were made in the refining of edible oils and fats from seeds and kernels grown in the British Colonies which formerly were largely imported by Germany. The capacity of oil-refining factories has been increased during 1918 roughly from 4,250 tons to nearly 10,750 tons, and the margarine factories from about 5,000 tons to 9,500 tons,per week. Even in the event of a failure of the butter supply the margarine machinery would be adequate. Previous to the control of margarine various grades were placed on the market of good, bad, and indifferent quality, hut since the inception of a fixed working formula by the Ministry the quality has been uniformly improved so that at the present time, despite war conditions, the public are consuming a better article than at any other previous time. Further important steps are being taken by the Ministry to benefit the trade by the grading of seeds, kernels, and oils so as to establish recognisable qualities to be maintained by the adoption of standard contracts, and by the encouragement of research in the use and properties of the articles. SUPPLIES. Bacon - Hams, and Lard. The demand for bacon keeps low, although the quality supplied to the trade has greatly improved. With regard to the question of a revision of retail prices in England, it has been decided that while the retailer, and more particularly the small retailer, may have had difficulties to contend with in the matter of an inferior assortment of bacon, the position, taken as a whole, is not such as to justify the Bacon Division in asking the Food Controller to assent.to any increase in the maximum price. Stocks of lard in hand, and anticipated purchases, are sufficient not only to allow lard to be released from the coupon, but to allot a certain amount weekly to manu- facturers whoat present receive only " compound " for manufacturing purposes. It is, however, intended to maintain the registration of customers and the present system of distribution, so that the machinery for rationing will be complete if circumstances make it necessary to institute it afresh, .! Dried Fruits.-The release of dried fruits for the Christmas trade is proceeding satisfactorily, sufficient sultanas being available to allow 25 per cent, of the datumperiod quantity of this variety to be Released. Meat. Reports from areas all over the country indicate that an appreciable quantity of live stock was held back from the markets last week in order that farmers should reap the benefit of the advanced prices which came into operation on the 1st December. At the same time the increases in the market during the current week aro not expected to be maintained for any appreciable time. No meat has so far been diverted to the recently liberated countries, but there is no doubt that demands will shortly have to be met. The necessity for increasing the output of frozen meat is still urgent owing to the difficulty expected in pro Adding storage space for later arrivals, but the reports received from the country show that there is considerable doubt whether the public will take advantage of the double ration which is to be made available for them during Christmas week. This doubt is strengthened by the concessions which have been made in the direction of freeing poultry and game from the coupon. The future demand for meat will probably be adversely affected by the prices now required. The reports received already indicate a diminution in the purchasing power of the public, and the problem is likely to arise of providing an adequate ration for the industrial community at prices which they are able to pay. It has been announced to committees and to the public that, from Sunday, 1st December, until further notice, the following classes of meat may be sold by retailers and served as part of a meal by caterers without requiring the' surrender of meat coupons : Edible offal, including tongues, kidneys and skirt and all other edible offal of cattle, sheep and pigs mentioned in the Uniform Schedule of Maximum Retail Prices for Offal; and imported tenderloins from cattle. This concession also applies to institutions. Potatoes. The recent shortage of potatoes in London has been terminated, and there are now abundant supplies of potatoes coming forward into all the London markets. It is proposed to carry out certain modifications in the Potato Distribution Scheme to make the Scheme less rigid, and it is hoped that these alterations will' come into force on the 12th instant. The Board of Agriculture estimate that the stocks of potatoes on hand in England and Wales on the 1st November 1918 was 700,000 tons in excess of the stocks in the country on the corresponding date last year. Arrangements have already been made ior the export of 10,000 tons to France, and it will probably be found necessary to export further quantities later in the season. Tea.-Nearly 2,500,000 lbs. of the 3,000,000 lbs. of China tea purchased by the Ministry of Food is being shipped on a vessel leaving Shanghai during the present month. DIVISIONAL REPORTS. South Wales.-Representatives of the Ministry of Food were invited to attend a conference of miners delegates in South Wales on the 2nd of December. The delegates' complaints chiefly concerned unequal distribution. They also declared that the present rations of meat, sugar, and butter were insufficient to keep them in bodily health. The representatives of the Ministry present explained in reply the reality of the shortage of available supplies, and why the signing of the Armistice could not afford immediate relief to the situation in this respect. The delegates received the replies in a very good spirit, and evidently appreciated the reasons given as to why it is impossible at present to relax the restrictions on the rationed articles. Scotland East. Prisoners of war repatriated from germany are arriving in large numbers at the Port of Leith, where they are receiving a magnificent welcome from the citizens. The Scottish Branch of the Red Cross Society, who have made special arrangements for their comfort, have asked for the release of dried fruits to make fruit cake for 10,000 men. ORDERS UNDER DEFENCE OF THE REALM REGULATIONS. I. The Apples (Prices) Order, 1918,-dated)d4th November 1918, controls the price of all home-grown and imported apples. The maximum retail price is Qd.1 per lb; The Order comes into force on December 16th, and revokes the Apples and Perry Pears (Sales) Order, 1918. i- .2. The Horseflesh (Maximum Prices) Order, 1918, dated 30th November 1918, fixes maximum wholesale and retail prices for horseflesh. Notices of sale and prices must be kept posted in a conspicuous position by retailers. 3. The Milk (Restriction in Establishments) Order, 1018, dated 30th. November1918, prohibits the serving of milk as a beverage in any catering or residentialestablishment, except under a medical certificate, and also provides for the rationingin bulk of milk in establishments. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS. The number of prosecutions has dropped in the past week by 250 cases. The total number for the week is 859, with 768 convictions. The prosecutions are reported under 64 different Orders, those heading the listbeing the Flour Restriction (Ireland) Order with 189 cases, the Tea (Retail Prices)Order with 112 cases, and the Rationing Order, 1918, with 101 cases. Imprisonment. A sentence of 21 days' imprisonment, without option, wasinflicted on Florence Breman, housekeeper, for using a ration bookjllegally obtained. A number of cases are reported in which ingenious attempts have been made to evade the Orders controlling the prices of intoxicating liquors. It is said that hotel-keepers make a practice of closing down the public bar and compelling customers toobtain their drinks in other parts of the houses where higher prices are charged. PART II.-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. IMPORTS. Average imports only arrived in the week ended 30th November (181,400 tons).As compared with the preceding weeks there were substantial increases in meat(increase 16,600 tons), bacon (increase 4,200 tons), rice (increase 6,000 tons), sugar(increase 4,400 tons), and tea (increase 9,300 tons). There was again a good import of oats (15,200 tons), but maize (2,800 tons), was still low, and practically no barleyarrived. The import of tea (12,800 tons), was the highest recorded in any week (with one exception) during the past two years. There were also good imports of eggs(1,200 tons), poultry, lemons (1,800 tons), and oranges (3,500 tons), but no bananas. The total imports for the first 13 weeks of the cereal years 1917-18 and1918-19 are compared in the following table : Total Imports in the first 13 weeks of cereal year. 1917. 1918. Increase or Decrease. 1917. 1918. Increase or Decreazr.Total -Wheat -Flour Equivalent as Grain. Barley, oats, and maize. Rice Meat Tons. 2,131,000 476,900 224,200 Tons. 2,362,700 1,139,700 119,400 Tons. 4- 231,700 4 662,800 - 104,800 Bacon Lard Butter -Margarine Cheese -Condensed milk Sugar Tea Coffee -Cocoa Tons. 59,700 3,000 10,200 12,400 44,200 23,300 401,100 27,800 1,700 4,500 1 ons. 118,500 38,200 8,500 33,100 40,700 323,400 61,600 2,500 19,100 Tons. 4 58,800 4 35,200 - 1,700 - 12,400 - 11,100 4 17,400 - 77,700 4 33,800 4 800 4 14,600 771,900 1,288,900 4 517,000 524,500 158,100 "159,400 305,500 20,700 131,800 - 219,000 - 137,400 - 27,600 CONSUMPTION. Provisions. The returns of sales by multiple shops and co-operative stores showan all-round decline in the four weeks ended November 23rd, compared with thepreceding four weeks. The fall in bacon sales has been continuous since the high level reached in June. The present sales are 16 per cent, below those of thepreceding four weeks, 38 per cent, below those of June, and about 14 per cent, belowthe general average for 1916-17. They are, of course, very much higher (51 percent.) than those of a year, ago, when there was a bacon shortage which lasted until april 1918. 'Cheese shows a fall of 14 per cent, on the sales in the preceding four weeks, no doubt caused by a shortage of supplies, the quantities released by theMinistry having been reduced from. 3,400 tons to ^,200 tons. The returns show thatcheese stocks are low, having fallen from seven to six days' supply. Butter sales have declined a further 35 per cent, compared with the preceding four weeks. The fall isseasonal, but its degree is intensified by the re-adjustment of the butter and margarineration. Bread and Flour. The fall in the quantity of flour used for bread and sold bvbakers in the four weeks ended November 9th (Table C (2)) has been followed by adecrease of 6 per cent, in the quantities of flour released by millers and issued toagents in the four weeks ended November 23rd (Table B (1)). Tea. The large imports and stocks of tea referred to above have been accompanied by large increases jn the quantities balloted for (Table B (1)), thefour-weekly average having increased from 2,500 tons a week in the four weeks ended October 12th to 4,200 tons a week in the four weeks ended November 23rd.This is equal to nearly 4 ozs. per head of the total population of all ages. Meat. The estimated consumption of home-grown butchers7 meat in GreatBritain in the week ended 23rd November showed a slight increase on the preceding,weeks. The quantity of refrigerated meat issued rose further to 1,800 tons, but,of *this 1,100 tons consisted of boneless beef and offals. The estimated total consumptionof meat sold against coupons, after deductions for waste, was 16,900 tons. Theincrease in the meat consumption in the United Kingdom (Table B (1)) is due partly to the increase of imported meat falling outside the ration ; but mainly to theincreased slaughter of cattle in Ireland, no doubt partly due to the restrictions onthe; exportation of cattle from Ireland. STOCKS. During the week ended 23rd November stocks of beef, were enlarged by 5,700tons while other meat declined 1,000 tons, due no doubt to the release of offals fromrationing. The stocks of condensed milk declined .1,700 tons, otherwise there'was no material change. Ministry storage was reduced by 6,000 tons of bacon, and increasedby 1,500 tons of lard and 1,200 tons of butter. Live Stock--The estimated number of live stock in Great Britain on the 4thNovember shows an improvement on last year's figures under all heads except thoseof ewes kept for breeding where the fall is from 12,966,000 to 9,150,000 (29 per cent.).Dairy cattle show an increase of 7 per cent., total cattle 5 per cent., sheep 1 per cent.,breeding sows 24 per cent., and total pigs 5 per cent. It must be borne in mind,however, that the average weights have fallen. TABLE A.-IMPORTS OF PRINCIPAL FOOD AND FEEDING STUFFS.Artiole. 1. Week ending November 1 30th, 1918. 2. UNITED KINGDOM. Tlio figures for wheat and Hour iuolude stocks iu port granaries and warehouses, inland warehouses,mills, and bakers' shops, as well as estimated stocks on farms; those for barley, oats, beans, and peasinclude stocks in port granaries and warehouses and in mills, in maltsters' hands, and estimated farm stocks;those for maize, rice, and grain meals include stocks-in port granaries aud warehouses and iu mills. The'figures for sugar aro stocks in possession of the Sugar Commission ; those for butter, margarine,lard, cheese, condensed milk, meat, and fish include stocks at ports, in cold stores, and in importers' andwholesalers' warehouses. The figures for tea, coffee, and cocoa are stocks remaining in bonded warehouses or entered to bewarehoused; and those for oilseeds and oilseed cake include stocks at ports and in the hands of millers,crushers, and cake manufacturers.Article.November 1st. 1918.October 1st, 1918. j November lit, 1917.1Stocks in the United Kingdom including estimated Farm Stocks.Wheat (including flour)f -Barley f -Oatsf -Beansf -PeasfMaize - -Rice (including ground rice and rice flour)Grain Meals - -Sugar... - -Butter ;-Margarine,' - - -Lard * -Cheese -" , - - -Condensed Milk -Meat:-Beef (chilled and frozen) '.
